raw_text:
Saudi investor picks up the Savoy
 
 London's famous Savoy hotel has been sold to a group combining Saudi billionaire investor Prince Alwaleed bin Talal and a unit of HBOS bank.
 
 Financial details of the deal, which includes the nearby Simpson's in the Strand restaurant, were not disclosed. The seller - Irish-based property firm Quinlan Private - bought the Savoy along with the Berkeley, Claridge's and the Connaught for £750m last year. Prince Alwaleed's hotel investments include the luxury George V in Paris. He also has substantial stakes in Fairmont Hotels & Resorts, which will manage the Savoy and Simpson's in the Strand, and Four Seasons. Fairmont said it planned to invest $48m (£26m) in renovating parts of the Savoy including the River Room and suites with views over the River Thames. Work was expected to be completed by summer 2006, Fairmont said.
llama3.2:1b: Saudi billionaire Prince Alwaleed bin Talal has purchased the Savoy hotel, along with other hotels in London, for £750m. Quinlan Private, an Irish property firm, acquired the properties including the nearby Simpson's restaurant last year. The sale includes a deal to renovate the River Room and suites at Fairmont Hotels & Resorts' Savoy.

The sale includes the hotel investments of Prince Alwaleed, who also owns luxury hotels such as the George V in Paris, and was joined by a unit of HBOS bank.

The deal includes the nearby Simpson's restaurant in the Strand restaurant district. Prince Alwaleed's hotels include George V in Paris and Fairmont Hotels & Resorts managing the Savoy and Simpson's in the Strand. Work on renovating parts of the Savoy will be completed by summer 2006. Fairmont said it plans to invest $48m (£26m) in renovating parts of the Savoy including the River Room and suites with views over the River Thames, expected to be completed by summer 2006.

The seller bought the property last year and plans renovations including river views. Work is expected to be completed by summer 2006.

The deal includes investments from Fairmont Hotels & Resorts which will manage the Savoy and invest $48m (£26m) to renovate parts of the property, expected to be completed by summer 2006.

Prince Alwaleed's hotel investments include the luxury George V in Paris, He also has substantial stakes in Fairmont Hotels & Resorts (which will manage the Savoy and Simpson's in the Strand), Four Seasons.
smollm:1.7b: The Saudi investor has bought up a significant portion of the Savoy hotel from a unit of HBOS bank in London. The deal includes the nearby Simpson's in the Strand restaurant and is worth £750 million. Prince Alwaleed's investments include the luxury George V in Paris, which he also owns shares in Fairmont Hotels & Resorts, which will manage the Savoy and Simpson's in the Strand. The hotel was previously owned by Four Seasons Hotels & Resorts. Work is expected to be completed by summer 2006 on renovating parts of the Savoy including the River Room and suites with views over the River Thames.
deepseek-r1:1.5b:
<think>
Alright, so I need to summarize this text about a sale between two companies related to the Savoy hotel in London. Let me read through it carefully first.

The text says that Saudi investors bought the Savoy hotel from Quinlan Private for £750 million last year. That's interesting because it shows that private equity firms can take such luxury properties, which are known to appreciate quickly due to their status.

Now, Prince Alwaleed bin Talal, a prominent Saudi investor and CEO of HBOS bank, is the one who bought the Savoy. He has investments in some of the hotel's properties, like the George V in Paris. That makes sense because high-end luxury properties often attract big investors looking for a catch.

The seller is Quinlan Private, an Irish-based property firm, which makes sense since Prince is based there. They bought the Savoy, Simpson's, and another property before. The financial details of this deal weren't disclosed yet, so the exact numbers are probably not provided right now.

Speaking of financials, Fairmont Hotels & Resorts has a plan to renovate parts of the Savoy. Specifically, they'll invest $48 million in renovations like the River Room and suites with views over the Thames. They expect this work to be done by summer 2006. That's pretty soon for such renovations, which is good because hotels usually need updates to stay modern and attract guests.

Also, Fairmont mentioned that they'll manage Simpson's in the Strand restaurant. Simpson's is a well-known chain of fine dining restaurants nearby. This shows how these companies might work together on managing each other's properties, especially since they're close geographically.

I should make sure I capture all the key points: Saudi investors buying the Savoy from Quinlan, Prince Alwaleed having some high-end hotel investments, Fairmont managing both the Savoy and Simpson's, and their financial plan for renovations. I need to keep it concise without any explanations or formatting.
</think>

Prince Alwaleed bin Talal, a prominent Saudi investor, purchased the Savoy hotel from Irish-based property firm Quinlan Private in £750 million last year. The deal included Simpson's in the Strand restaurant. Fairmont Hotels & Resorts plans to invest $48 million in renovating parts of the Savoy, including the River Room and suites offering views over the Thames.
tinyllama:1.1b: A Saudi investor has acquired a major stake in London's iconic Savoy hotel for £750m. The deal includes two other historic hotels, Berkeley and Claridge's, as well as the George V Paris hotel. In addition to his hotel investments, Prince Alwaleed bin Talal has substantial stakes in Fairmont Hotel Group, which will manage the Savoy and Simpson's in the Strand restaurant. The sale was completed last year and includes $48m (£26m) of renovations for the Savoy including views of the River Thames. Work is expected to be completed by summer 2006, according to Fairmont.
tinydolphin:1.1b: The Savoy Hotel, a renowned British landmark known for its exquisite dining experiences and impeccable service, has recently been purchased by a Saudi investor, Prince Alwaleed bin Talal, for an undisclosed sum. The deal involves the purchase of the near-by Simpson's restaurant in the Strand and the Savoy Hotel itself, as well as the nearby Berkeley, Claridge's, and George V hotels. This sale is a significant step forward for Quinlan Private Properties, as it demonstrates their keen interest in investing in high-quality assets worldwide.
phi:2.7b: A Saudi investor has bought London's famous Savoy hotel along with two other hotels for £750m, which will be managed by Irish property firm Quinlan Private's subsidiary, Fairmont Hotels & Resorts. Prince Alwaleed bin Talal is one of the investors in Fairmont Hotels.

The buyer, Quinlan Private, bought the property firm and a unit of HBOS bank with the Savoy and Claridge's hotel. The buyer is also investing $48m to renovate parts of the Savoy and the Simpson's restaurant. Fairmont plans to invest $26m in updating parts of the hotel. The Savoy is known for its luxury George V hotel in Paris and other hotels such as Four Seasons.

Fairmont Hotels & Resorts will manage the properties, investing $48 million ($26 million) in renovations at the Savoy including the River Room and suites with views over the River Thames, expected to be completed by summer 2006.

Financial details were not disclosed. Prince Alwaleed, who has significant stakes in Fairmont Hotels & Resorts and Four Seasons, also owns the luxury George V in Paris. Fairmont, which will manage the Savoy, plans to invest $48 million in renovations, including the River Room and suites overlooking the Thames, with completion expected by summer 2006.

This acquisition follows his investment in other iconic British hotels: Berkeley, Claridge's, and Connaught. Prince Alwaleed also holds significant shares in Fairmont Hotels & Resorts, which will oversee the Savoy and Simpson's renovations. Fairmont plans to invest $48m (£26m) in upgrading parts of the Savoy, including the River Room and suites with Thames views, with completion expected by summer 2006.
